title-group.article-title: No Increased Risk of Spinal Cord Ischemia in Delayed AAA Repair Following Thoracic Aortic Surgery

article-meta.aff: 1Division of Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy, Department of Surgery, Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, USA
2Department of Anesthesiology and Critical Care, Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, USA
3Department of Neurology, Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, USA
4Division of Vascular and Endovascular Surgery, Department of Surgery, Cooper University Hospital, Camden, NJ, USA

author-notes.corresp: Benjamin M. Jackson, Division of Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy, Department of Surgery, Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, 4 Silverstein Pavilion, 3400 Spruce Street, Philadelphia, PA, USA. Email: benjamin.jackson@uphs.upenn.edu

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: To examine the results of open or endovascular abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) repair following prior open or endovascular thoracic aortic surgery.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: A retrospective review of all patients who underwent AAA repair in a delayed fashion following prior thoracic aortic surgery at a single university hospital between 1999 and 2011 was performed.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Thirteen patients underwent AAA repair following prior thoracic aortic repair. Mean age was 68.9 ± 6.9 years and 77% (n = 10) were male. Three patients experienced transient delayed-onset spinal cord ischemia (SCI) following initial thoracic surgery. Mean time interval between initial thoracic aortic surgery and subsequent AAA repair was 2.0 ± 1.8 years. Overall rate of SCI and 30-day mortality after delayed AAA repair was 0%.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: This series does not demonstrate any evidence of increased risk of perioperative mortality or SCI in patients undergoing delayed AAA repair after prior thoracic aortic surgery.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Historically, spinal cord ischemia (SCI) represented a not infrequent devastating complication of conventional open thoracic aortic surgery. Advances in endovascular technology and the concomitant growing utilization of thoracic endovascular aortic repair (TEVAR) to treat various aortic pathologies has significantly decreased, albeit not eliminated, the incidence of perioperative SCI. Contemporary series have reported incidences of SCI between 0% and 13% following TEVAR. 1
–5 Meanwhile, neurologic complications resulting from SCI after abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) repair remain rare, with incidences following elective open and endovascular AAA repairs reported to be less than 0.3%. 6 Peppelenbosch et al 7 recently conducted a review of the literature and demonstrated a mean incidence of 1.2% (range 0%-2.8%) after open repair for ruptured AAAs. In addition, several reports have cited a history of either repaired or unrepaired AAA as an independent risk factor for SCI in patients undergoing open or endovascular thoracic aortic surgery. 8 –10 A recent meta-analysis demonstrated significantly higher rates of mortality and morbidity, including SCI, in patients with prior AAA surgery who underwent open repair of thoraco-AAA (TAAA). 9

Despite an increasing body of evidence regarding the effect of prior AAA repair on perioperative outcomes of thoracic aortic surgery, the impact of prior thoracic aortic surgery on morbidity and mortality after AAA repair is yet to be explored. We report our experience with patients undergoing delayed AAA repair following prior thoracic aortic surgery. To our knowledge, the present study serves as the first reported series examining outcomes in this unique patient cohort.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: A retrospective review of a clinical database was performed in order to identify all patients who underwent open or endovascular AAA repair in a delayed fashion following prior open or endovascular thoracic aortic surgery at a single university hospital between 1999 and 2011. Crawford extent IV TAAA repairs were classified as abdominal aortic interventions. Patients undergoing operations involving aortic arch hybrid, abdominal debranching, or any abdominal aortic procedure requiring cardiopulmonary bypass were excluded. Baseline demographics, aortic pathology, acuity, intraoperative procedure-related variables, and perioperative outcomes were assessed for all patients during both the thoracic and the abdominal aortic interventions. Primary outcomes were in-hospital mortality and SCI. The extent of endovascular coverage of the descending thoracic aorta was classified into 3 groups extent A was coverage from the origin of the left subclavian artery to the sixth thoracic vertebral level; extent B was coverage from the sixth thoracic vertebral level to the diaphragm; and extent C was coverage of the entire descending thoracic aorta from the left subclavian artery to the diaphragm. Spinal cord ischemia was defined as any new lower extremity motor or sensory deficit in the postoperative period that was not attributed to stroke or peripheral neuropathy. Details regarding the spinal protection protocol implemented at our institution have been previously described. 1,11,12

sec.title: Initial Thoracic Aortic Intervention
sec.p: Thirteen patients underwent AAA repair (open, n = 6; endovascular aortic repair [EVAR], n = 7) following prior thoracic aortic surgery (open, n = 2; TEVAR, n = 11) during the study period. Mean age at the time of initial thoracic aortic surgery was 68.9 ± 6.9 years, and 77% (n = 10) were male. Baseline demographics and comorbidities are listed in Table 1. Indications for thoracic aortic intervention included descending thoracic aortic aneurysm (n = 10), TAAA (extent I, n = 1; extent III, n = 1), and acute Stanford type B aortic dissection (n = 1; Table 2). Mean thoracic aortic aneurysm diameter was 6.4 ± 1.2 cm. In all, 54% (n = 7) of the cases were performed electively, with the remainder performed urgently or emergently due to back pain (n = 4), contained rupture (n = 1), or malperfusion (n = 1). All procedures were performed under general anesthesia. Of the 11 patients who underwent TEVAR, 4 had extent C endovascular coverage (coverage of the entire descending thoracic aorta). Left subclavian artery coverage was required in 4 patients, all of whom underwent a preemptive left subclavian artery revascularization procedure. A median of 3 stent grafts (range 1-6) were used in each endovascular case. Thoracic aortic stent grafts used included the TAG (n = 3 patients; W.L. Gore & Associates, Flagstaff, Arizona), Talent (n = 4 patients; Medtronic Inc, Minneapolis, Minnesota), Valiant (n = 1 patient; Medtronic Inc), and Zenith TX2 (n = 3 patients; Cook Medical, Bloomington, Indiana). Partial left heart bypass (left atrial-to-femoral artery bypass) was used in both patients who underwent open TAAA repair. In total, 5 patients had prophylactic cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) drains placed preoperatively at the time of thoracic aortic intervention and 2 patients had CSF drains inserted postoperatively for neurologic changes. Intraoperative somatosensory-evoked potential (SSEP) monitoring was used in 6 cases.

fn.p: Abbreviations: CAD, coronary artery disease; MI, myocardial infarction; CRI, chronic renal insufficiency; COPD, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; PVD, peripheral vascular disease; CHF, congestive heart failure; SD, standard deviation.
aAge at initial thoracic aortic intervention.

Abbreviations: SCI, spinal cord ischemia; SSEP, intraoperative somatosensory-evoked potential monitoring; TAA, thoracic aortic aneurysm; TEVAR, thoracic endovascular aortic repair; TAAA, thoracoabdominal aortic aneurysm; AAA, abdominal aortic aneurysm; EVAR, endovascular aortic repair; Sx, symptomatic; R, ruptured; M, malperfusion; mo, months.

a Extent endovascular coverage, extent A, coverage from distal to the left subclavian artery to the T6 vertebral level; extent B, coverage from T6 to diaphragmatic hiatus; extent C, coverage of the entire descending thoracic aorta.
b Endovascular coverage of the left subclavian artery.
d Time interval between thoracic and abdominal aortic interventions, in months.
e Underwent preemptive left subclavian artery revascularization procedure.
f Coil embolization of unilateral internal iliac artery.

sec.p: Transient, delayed onset SCI occurred in 3 patients after their initial descending thoracic or thoracoabdominal aortic repair. The first patient was a 56-year-old male with a history of a rapidly expanding 6.9-cm extent I TAAA and chronic Stanford type B aortic dissection who presented with severe back pain. Prophylactic lumbar CSF drainage and intraoperative SSEP monitoring were used. He underwent urgent open repair and at that time 6 pairs of intercostal arteries were reimplanted. His initial postoperative course was unremarkable and his lumbar drain was removed on postoperative day 2. On postoperative day 3, the patient developed profound bilateral lower extremity weakness in the setting of new-onset atrial fibrillation and associated hypotension. Within 1 hour of initiation of vasopressor therapy, the patient fully recovered lower extremity motor strength. The second patient was a 75-year-old male who underwent an urgent TEVAR with extent C coverage for a symptomatic 5.4-cm thoracic aortic aneurysm. Prophylactic lumbar CSF drainage and intraoperative neuromonitoring were not used in this case due to the acuity of presentation. On postoperative day 1, the patient demonstrated unilateral lower extremity paraparesis. The patient achieved full neurologic recovery within 48 hours following prompt initiation of lumbar drainage and blood pressure augmentation. The third patient was a 64-year-old woman with an 8.3-cm thoracic aortic aneurysm and associated back pain who underwent an urgent TEVAR with extent C coverage. Prophylactic lumbar CSF drainage and intraoperative neuromonitoring were not used due to the acuity of her presentation. The patient demonstrated unilateral lower extremity paraparesis on postoperative day 6 that promptly resolved with augmentation of arterial blood pressure.

Additional postoperative complications following thoracic aortic surgery included stroke (n = 2), acute renal failure (n = 1), external iliac artery dissection requiring stenting (n = 1), and new-onset arrhythmia (n = 1). Overall mean intensive care unit (ICU) and total hospital length of stay was 2.2 ± 1.6 (range 1-6) and 7.8 ± 4.8 (range 3-20) days, respectively. The majority (85%) of patients were discharged home; 2 patients required interim stays at rehabilitation facilities.

sec.title: Delayed Abdominal Aortic Intervention
sec.p: The mean time interval between initial thoracic aortic surgery and subsequent AAA repair was 2.0 ± 1.8 years (range 0.15- 5.4 years). Mean AAA diameter was 6.0 ± 1.2 cm. Indications for operation included AAA size >5.5 cm alone (n = 4), rapid aneurysmal expansion (n = 8), and back pain (n = 1). All cases were performed electively with general anesthesia. Preoperative imaging demonstrated patent bilateral hypogastric arteries in 12 patients, with only 1 patient having radiographic evidence of chronic bilateral hypogastric artery occlusion. Stent graft deployment was technically successful in all cases. Abdominal aortic stent grafts used included the following: Zenith (n = 5 patients; Cook Inc (Bloomington, IN), AneuRx (n = 1 patient; Medtronic Inc), and Endologix (n = 1 patient; Endologix Inc, Irvine, California). One patient who underwent EVAR had planned unilateral internal iliac artery coverage requiring coil embolization. The remaining 6 patients underwent open repair, including 1 juxtarenal AAA, 2 infrarenal AAA, and 3 extent IV TAAA repairs. All open repairs were performed via a retroperitoneal approach, and each case utilized a tube graft. Either a supraceliac (n = 3) or infrarenal (n = 3) clamp was used. At the time of delayed AAA repair, 54% (n = 7) of the patients had prophylactic lumbar CSF drainage and 46% (n = 6) had intraoperative SSEP monitoring. Of note, both prophylactic lumbar CSF drainage and intraoperative neuromonitoring were used in all the 3 patients who developed SCI following their initial thoracic aortic intervention.

Overall, in-hospital mortality was 0%. None of the patients demonstrated any neurologic deficits associated with SCI following their delayed abdominal aortic procedure. Other postoperative complications included respiratory failure (n = 1), acute renal failure (n = 1), and takeback for bleeding (n = 1). Overall mean ICU and total hospital length of stay was 3.6 ± 5.8 (range 1-21) and 10.0 ± 9.0 (range, 3-34) days, respectively. In all, 77% of the patients (n = 10) were discharged directly to home. The remaining 3 patients were discharged to either a rehabilitation (n = 2) or to a long-term acute care facility (n = 1).

At a mean follow-up period of 2.1 ± 2.4 years (range 0.04-8.5 years), 77% of the patients remain alive. No patients have required any form of secondary intervention. One- and 2-year Kaplan-Meier survival rates were 92% ± 7% and 69% ± 15%, respectively, with zero incidence of delayed onset SCI (Figure 1).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The spinal cord has a complex and highly variable blood supply that is dependent upon the integration of both longitudinal arterial trunks and a widespread collateral network (Figures 2 and 3). Translational research has led to the formulation of the collateral network concept, a model for comprehending and optimizing spinal cord perfusion during and after aortic surgery. 13 This concept underscores the important contribution of various collateral pathways to the net vascular supply of the spinal cord, including those vascular territories supplied by subclavian, intercostal, lumbar, hypogastric, and other smaller pelvic arteries.

caption.p: Extensive collateral network supplying the spinal cord (Adopted with permission from Ullery et al35).
Distal aortic and pelvic collaterals that become important during abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) repair (Adopted with permission from Ullery et al35).

sec.p: Recruitment of collateral pathways to the spinal cord becomes critically important following treatment of multilevel aortic disease since such cases uniformly result in more widespread disruption of the available collateral circulation. Deployment of thoracic aortic stent grafts results in rapid complete occlusion of varying lengths of intercostal and segmental arteries, whereas deployment of abdominal aortic stent grafts leads to complete occlusion of the inferior mesenteric, iliolumbar, and pelvic arteries originating in the infrarenal aorta. In addition, open thoracic or abdominal aortic surgery is associated with a host of additional perioperative events that may directly or indirectly compromise the integrity of remaining collateral vessels, including aortic cross-clamping, intraoperative hypotension, atheromatous embolization, and ligation of intercostal, inferior mesenteric, and/or iliolumbar arteries. Planned sacrifice of 1 or both the hypogastric arteries may further decrease available pelvic collaterals to the spinal cord. 14 –16

Prior reports have demonstrated that both simultaneous and staged aortic repairs are technically feasible. The risk of SCI, however, may vary considerably relative to the timing and approach to such surgical interventions. We recently reported our experience treating combined thoracic and AAA simultaneously with endoluminal stent grafts in 8 patients. 17 Thoracic endovascular aortic repair was performed prior to EVAR in these cases. Despite one-half of these procedures being performed emergently, there were no in-hospital deaths and none of the patients in our series developed acute myocardial infarction, acute renal failure, or permanent neurologic complications. One patient did, however, develop transient lower extremity paraparesis that resolved with blood pressure augmentation. Smaller case series and case reports have also failed to demonstrate any increased risk of SCI or mortality with simultaneous endovascular repair of concomitant multilevel aortic disease. 18 –20 Earlier studies evaluating the results of hybrid repair with thoracic stent grafts and an open abdominal approach have shown similar findings. 21
–24

Results regarding morbidity and mortality after staged repairs have been less favorable and are limited to those involving patients undergoing initial AAA repair followed by delayed thoracic aortic surgery. Our experience has shown that 40% to 50% of the patients who develop SCI after TEVAR also have a history of prior open or endovascular AAA repair. 1,11 In a retrospective review of 261 patients undergoing TEVAR, Martin et al 25 showed that patients with a concomitant or previously repaired AAA were associated with a greater than 4-fold increase in the risk of SCI. Similarly, Baril et al 8 observed an increased incidence of SCI in patients with a history of repaired or unrepaired AAA compared to patients without AAA (14.3% vs 1.0%). Several previous reports have also documented higher incidences of SCI and mortality in patients with prior AAA who undergo delayed open thoracic or thoracoabdominal aortic surgery. 26
–29

The present study serves as the first report to explore outcomes in patients with prior thoracic aortic surgery followed by delayed AAA repair. Such patients represent a unique cohort and provide complementary information regarding the impact of timing in sequential, or staged, multilevel aortic interventions. Despite a conceptually similar net insult on the spinal cord collateral pathways relative to patients who undergo initial AAA repair followed by delayed thoracic aortic surgery, we found no evidence of increased risk of SCI or mortality in our series of 13 patients. The mean time interval between aortic interventions in our series (2.0 ± 1.8 years) appears considerably less than that observed in cases involving prior AAA surgery and subsequent TAAA repair, with reported mean time intervals ranging from 6.4 to 9.5 years. 28,30
–33

Patients with prior thoracic aortic surgery who undergo delayed AAA repair may self-select themselves as lower risk patients relative to other patients with multilevel aortic disease given that they, at the time of the second intervention, have already demonstrated the ability to tolerate the procedure of greater relative magnitude and relative risk of neurologic complications (ie, thoracic or thoracoabdominal aortic surgery). Future investigation is warranted to better elucidate the precise impact of timing and sequence in staged aortic interventions.

The finding that patients undergoing descending thoracic aortic surgery after prior AAA repair are at increased risk of SCI but patients undergoing AAA repair after prior descending thoracic repairs are at reduced risk of SCI is difficult to explain. One possible explanation may be that patients with coexisting AAA have a high likelihood of severe distal aortic and peripheral vascular disease with compromised vascular supply to the spinal cord from lumbar, hypogastric, and pelvic collaterals. Such a pattern of disease would predict an increased risk of SCI after isolated open descending thoracic aortic repair or TEVAR as a consequence of thoracic segmental artery occlusion in patients with coexisting AAA. In contrast, the risk of SCI after open or endovascular AAA repair in patients with or without prior descending thoracic aortic repair is minimal because the spinal cord perfusion in these patients may not be dependent on lumbar, hypogastric, and pelvic vascular collaterals. Consistent with this hypothesis was the observation that 3 (23%) of our 13 patients with multilevel aortic disease experienced SCI after descending thoracic aortic repair despite the absence of surgical interventions on the distal aorta at the time of thoracic aortic surgery. This hypothesis is also consistent with the existing published experience that TEVAR in patients with prior distal aortic repairs are at increased risk of SCI. 8,25 According to this hypothesis, the risk of SCI after TEVAR in patients with prior AAA repair was more the consequence of severe preexisting distal aortic vascular disease and less the consequence of surgical interruption of lumbar, hypogastric, and pelvic collaterals from the surgical repair. This pathophysiologic condition would also explain the increased risk of SCI observed in the early experience of simultaneous TEVAR and EVAR. 21,34 Finally, this hypothesis would predict that delayed open or endovascular AAA repair in patients following prior thoracic aortic surgery would be associated with a minimal risk of SCI because the spinal cord vascular supply is not dependent on lumbar, hypogastric, or pelvic collaterals. Although this explanation may be compelling, the small sample size in this clinical series limits the strength of any possible conclusion. Additional clinical experience will be necessary to validate the findings of this study and any accompanying physiologic rationale for these observations.

Approximately, one-half of the patients in our series had prophylactic lumbar CSF drainage at the time of delayed AAA repair, including all 3 patients who evidenced SCI during their initial thoracic aortic intervention. The efficacy of blood pressure augmentation, prophylactic lumbar CSF drainage, and intraoperative neurophysiologic monitoring in the setting of AAA repair in patients having a history of previous descending thoracic aortic repairs remains unclear, however, and requires validation with a larger clinical experience.

Delayed open or endovascular AAA repair following prior open or endovascular thoracic aortic surgery is technically feasible. Although small and heterogenous, this series of patients does not demonstrate evidence any increased risk of perioperative mortality or SCI even in patients who had previously experienced transient SCI during prior thoracic aortic intervention. There is uncertain benefit to the routine use of prophylactic lumbar drainage in this unique patient cohort. As endovascular therapies continue to evolve and are applied to an expanding group of aortic pathologies, knowledge regarding the optimal timing (simultaneous or staged), approach (open, endovascular, or hybrid), and sequence of treating multilevel aortic disease becomes increasingly important.
